title: Cursive font
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091004032049im_/http:/typophile.com/files/airfont_4503.jpg)

Scanned from a Japanese music magazine, published earlier this year.
author: galerian_ash

comments.content:
It’s an unfamiliar script to me, but for something similar, while I still search, look at [Asturias](http://web.archive.org/web/20091004032049/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/insigne/asturias/) from Insigne fonts.

- Mike Yanega

That was the closest I found at MyFonts. Now I am going to look at Veer.

- Mike Yanega

There was nothing closer at Veer. I wouldn’t know where else to see a large collection of script fonts that wouldn’t have been at those two sites.

Anyone else? Is it custom? At this point that would be my guess.

- Mike Yanega

Look at how i-n and t-h connect. If that is custom, then by someone who is not familiar with latin alphabet handwriting. The OP said “Japanese” :-)

Andreas

Mike: Thank you for the effort, you really went through a lot of fonts there! Asturias might not be a perfect match, but I definately like it — so thanks for pointing me in its direction :)

Andreas: I noticed that too! The way the letters connect seems unique; I don’t think I’ve ever seen anything like it in cursive writing/typography.

...Anyway, in case you’re curious to see more of it, I scanned the other two instances of it being used in the magazine. It’s a shame if it indeed is a custom job; it seems to be a complete enough font, and it really is quite lovely.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091004032049im_/http:/typophile.com/files/airfont2_4915.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091004032049im_/http:/typophile.com/files/airfont3_5798.jpg)

/Annette

Andreas, I am not sure about what you say. Take a look at how characters connect in Metroscript from Alphabet Soup for instance, very similar. It rather seems to be a design decision than not knowing Western handwriting.

—- Tamas Ferencz —-

Mmh... Metroscript is a rather tight script font where that makes at least some sense. I would compare this one rather to a font like Bickley Script. But let’s call it a design decision anyway, on the basis that there are good decisions as well as bad ones ;-)
